data.text: We will need to provide economic stimulus until we see inflation sustainably reach our aim, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta @Unibocconi. Policy support will have to remain in place well beyond the end of the pandemic 1/5 https://t.co/oJymlMpc6j

It is important to withdraw fiscal stimulus very gradually, says Vice-President Luis de Guindos. Governments need to spend money to fight the consequences of the pandemic. Only once the pandemic is over should they once again work on consolidation https://t.co/ge3yio5OLw https://t.co/XtZ2Wocj6o

De Guindos: A centrally managed countercyclical macroprudential tool could be considered, with an increased role for the ECB Governing Council. Meanwhile, national authorities would retain their powers to address shocks at the national level 3/3

De Guindos: There seems to be a growing consensus on the need to reassess the current balance between structural and cyclical buffers and to create more macroprudential space for a system-wide crisis. This should not lead to additional buffer requirements for banks 2/3

(THREAD) Vice-President Luis de Guindos talks about two key challenges for macroprudential policy: creating macroprudential space through buffers and how monetary and macroprudential policy complement each other in a monetary and banking union https://t.co/zJHSLwSDo3 1/3 https://t.co/uUMM2KMf6W
Register now and watch live from 16:20 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos joins the @banquedefrance FSR conference to discuss macroprudential policy https://t.co/c9rNl9Jrbt https://t.co/GeldzSSqci

Banks are in much better shape than at the start of the last crisis, says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. We monitor their health to make sure they can absorb losses and keep lending to the economy. This is essential for a sustained recovery https://t.co/EjHkdTYn1d https://t.co/vDwtzXYw3q
Working Paper: Inventory management, dealers’ connections, and prices in OTC markets https://t.co/UIGxQX97nO

Lane on fiscal policy: The challenge in the near term is not the level of debt. The challenge now is to ensure that the economy makes it through the pandemic with as many workers and firms as possible in good shape, and in having a sustained recovery 3/3
Lane on yields: We are carefully monitoring the rise in yields and will conduct our bond purchases flexibly, if necessary 2/3

The secular decline in real interest rates requires us to rethink the optimal policy mix during economic downturns, says Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel. Successful macroeconomic stabilisation requires both unconventional monetary and fiscal policy https://t.co/nP3Qh0CWjK https://t.co/yDwBOFe09c

Register now and watch live from 9:30 CET on Friday: Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel talks about fiscal and monetary policy in an era of low inflation and low interest rates at the #EFBAnnualConference organised by @EFB_EU https://t.co/SrPRfsGesQ https://t.co/hCAJZJOCMW
Watch live from 16:00 CET: Vice-President Luis de Guindos joins a virtual @iesealumni event to talk about the economic recovery from the pandemic https://t.co/pDc0dKRA3X https://t.co/DNQRjr8T7H

Lane: Favourable financing conditions:

- reduce uncertainty for banks, firms, households and governments alike
- help prevent an undue tightening in a situation of an improving macroeconomic landscape
- underpin confidence in the recovery and in the eventual pick-up in inflation

(THREAD) Preserving favourable financing conditions for an extended period of time helps to support inflation developments, says Chief Economist Philip R. Lane. Read his speech https://t.co/FAUcJl4JXN 1/3 https://t.co/ESClXz14XT

Credit risk, internal governance and bank profitability remain high on the agenda for 2021. That’s the result of the 2020 supervisory review. Why is that and did the pragmatic approach adequately scrutinise banks? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/t2ETk2S55h
Research Bulletin: Nothing compares to your loan officer – continuity of relationships and loan renegotiation https://t.co/BSE09kqJ1J
How did euro area bank lending and money supply evolve in January? How do they compare with December’s figures? Find out more in the press release https://t.co/r8qOj5Fnvw https://t.co/TCtFo5iGxz

Fiscal and monetary policy are providing crucial support to counter the crisis, Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel tells @letanewslv. By preserving favourable financing conditions the ECB fosters the recovery and reinforces the fiscal response https://t.co/WTqDopvdAs https://t.co/QfYE3ruw9U

The focus for supervisors in Croatia and elsewhere remains the fallout from the pandemic. Structural transformation and asset quality are key for banks. Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria speaks about the first six months of close cooperation https://t.co/8ARH0GwFxj https://t.co/usW1q1b0L0

Digitalisation has become increasingly important in every area. That’s why European banking supervision is working on its digital transformation. What does this mean in practice and what are the main challenges? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/CgkvtN1EiS

Working paper: Limited liability, strategic default
and bargaining power (published in January 2021) https://t.co/mL8M2s1bIb
Congratulations @FrankElderson on your confirmation as Vice-Chair of the @ecb’s Supervisory Board. We wish you all the best for your five-year term of office. https://t.co/2MNNA8RYER

Governments and supervisory authorities took extraordinary measures in response to the pandemic. How were those decisions made and what will drive changes and adjustments in the future? Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/61W74uvDZ2

Lagarde: For Europe to be prepared and bring about positive change in 2021 and beyond, national and European decision-makers need to uphold our team effort. We at the ECB will continue to play our part 5/5 https://t.co/tTb4SpCPdA

Lagarde: As our economies reopen, the challenge will be to rapidly bring them back to fulfilling their potential, while using the thrust of the recovery to transform them. Digital and green technologies present huge possibilities for vibrant, inclusive and sustainable growth 4/5

Lagarde: The overall policy mix remains essential. By continuing to take the lead in protecting those most exposed to the crisis, fiscal policy can help brighten economic prospects for firms and people, thereby strengthening monetary policy transmission 3/5

(THREAD) Europe’s crisis response has crucially depended on the strength of national and European responses across all areas, President Lagarde said at European Parliamentary Week. Policy alignment will continue to be imperative for what lies ahead 1/5 https://t.co/tTb4SpCPdA https://t.co/7Yzy2lQwpZ

Smaller banks often find themselves in fierce competition with bigger ones. Does that also affect the way they price their loans? Do they adequately account for the risks involved? Read more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/gc9RF77UTR
Working paper: Regional economic impact of Covid-19: the role of sectoral structure and trade linkages https://t.co/kG3qPO2SQF

The proceedings of the 2020 ESCB Legal Conference are now available online! Discussed were highly topical legal issues such as climate change, central bank digital currencies and a constitutional debate: transparency vs. confidentiality. Read more here https://t.co/9oEpbS6lPI https://t.co/Lq8cQ56KiY

Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/VCqN1cH38O

The pandemic has put banks’ recovery plans to the test. To weather a system-wide storm of this kind, banks need to improve crucial parts of their recovery plans, supervisors say.  Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/J3pGcfn7FE

Diversity of experiences, backgrounds and gender among banks’ leaders is crucial, says Supervisory Board member Edouard Fernandez-Bollo. It will help banks face the challenges ahead. He explains how we will better support them in finding the right leaders https://t.co/L9WOnYd6tX https://t.co/75AXzD7zYX

The coronavirus pandemic has affected every aspect of our lives. But how was it for banks? Find out more about how supervisors help banks to be part of the solution during the crisis in the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast with host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/ZkvzRrY3Nb https://t.co/Ao3sP90VIW

We are not out of the woods just yet, says Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick assessing the supervisory measures taken to support the banking sector and the challenges that lie ahead. Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/lMOsu9SLgo https://t.co/EIGuz5LAnI
Account of the monetary policy meeting of the Governing Council of the ECB on 20-21 January 2021 https://t.co/FiHvi6jt2y

How does Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick assess the response to the pandemic? How sound are banks’ recovery plans? And where do we stand on the digitalisation of supervisory practices? Read about this and more in the Supervision Newsletter https://t.co/Ke53RJ4ILS https://t.co/lslXDIU2Gl

Did you know that the ECB carries out economic #research on topics ranging from monetary policy and inflation to financial stability and even crypto-assets? Take a look at our latest publications and find out more about our newly redesigned website https://t.co/WRjgzQ3fLF https://t.co/KYqxaFXQMa

‘Til the crisis is through

#ECBmyvalentine #ValentinesDay

Climate change needs urgent action and we must be committed to doing our part, says Executive Board member @FrankElderson. The EU Treaties provide substantial scope for the ECB to take action and tackle climate change https://t.co/D5lFR69Mhw #TheECBBlog https://t.co/GfsCrqYM4A https://t.co/gOlIT5FtwG

What are banking supervisors worried about for 2021? Why are “marriages” between banks a good idea? And how can supervisors help banks to be part of the solution during this crisis? Tune into the #TheECBPodcast with our host @MichaelSteen https://t.co/2vwrmyXgoY https://t.co/HOraIkZnd8
Working paper: Modeling extreme events - Time-varying extreme tail shape https://t.co/9U32tGS4yZ
Working paper: A multivariate unobserved components model to estimate potential output in the euro area - A production function based approach https://t.co/2PnxF8nenx

How can we ensure privacy when paying with a digital euro? What does a digital euro mean at the international level? What are the strengths of a digital euro over bitcoins?

Watch Executive Board member Fabio Panetta answering questions on the digital euro @bruegel_org https://t.co/AbAWtlgzvz

Panetta: Our objective would be to make a digital euro work with private payment solutions. It would level the playing field by making it possible for all market participants to offer, at a lower cost, products that allow people to pay instantly 4/4

Panetta: A digital euro would have the protection of privacy as a key priority, helping to maintain trust in payments. We have already analysed privacy-enhancing techniques, and we will continue to do so in the coming months 3/4

Panetta: A digital euro would be an efficient means of payment, not a form of investment. This would prevent people moving large deposits from commercial banks to the central bank and address risks to the international financial system 2/4

A digital euro would increase consumer choice, reduce costs and support the digitalisation of the economy, says Executive Board member Fabio Panetta. It would offer a safe means of payment and preserve money as a public good. Full speech https://t.co/0GNPEhGLPN 1/4 https://t.co/Oz9IDUbZcM

We asked and you responded! As part of our ongoing strategy review, we asked for your views on various topics. Read about what 4,000 of you told us:

➡️#ECBListens summary report https://t.co/Nei3lJs0Er

➡️#ECBListens Portal – summary of responses https://t.co/y7yAgaxM1V https://t.co/NL9xnwzw5G
Euro area securities issues statistics (Dec 2020) https://t.co/kOALFgClT4

Watch live from 16:00 CET: Chief Economist Philip R. Lane joins a panel to discuss economic policy in the post-Covid era at the Irish Fiscal Advisory Council’s annual conference. More information here https://t.co/2DlPIRFsrW 

#pfpf2021 @fiscalcouncil https://t.co/XIpUw4hUmi

Panetta: A digital euro project would allow us to further test the reaction and expectations of the public. Trialling it in different cities would also be a possibility.
 
What is a digital euro and how could it help? Discover more on our hub page https://t.co/RiwOCers68

Panetta: With cash, a digital euro would provide a simple, safe, reliable means of payment that is cost-free to use, protects data and is accepted in the euro area. The availability of central bank money for payments ensures that people are not dependent only on a few providers.

Looking for the latest eurozone #statistics releases? A wide range is available on our website – including statistics on eurozone policy rates, financial markets and various benchmark and interest rates. Take a look on our newly redesigned website https://t.co/Zrx9JMEzgD https://t.co/mT7zpQv55q
Lagarde: On the digital front, the increased use of digital technologies is changing all aspects of our lives, including how we pay. This is where our preparatory work on a digital euro comes in.
Lagarde: We will contribute to fighting climate change in line with our mandate. We have already started this process and we will continue to do more.

Lagarde: Fiscal policy – both at the national and at the European level – remains crucial to bolster the recovery in the euro area and address the impact of the pandemic. It can channel economic support to where it is most needed.

Lagarde: Favourable financing conditions are crucial to put the economic recovery on a self-sustaining trajectory. They reduce uncertainty, bolster confidence and will encourage spending and investment.
Lagarde: Citizens across Europe are still facing the dire social and economic consequences of the virus and prospects about the future remain uncertain.

Find out more about all our priorities https://t.co/wP33OKusFe https://t.co/fyQteN0g7x

The coronavirus has pushed down prices for travel-related services, one of the sectors most severely affected by the pandemic. This has been the main driver of the overall decline in services inflation. Read more https://t.co/NJoWHkrzft #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/hLVS6XVzmv

The pandemic is likely to hit disadvantaged households particularly hard and exacerbate existing differences. One reason for this is that housing costs tend to be resilient even when income levels fall. Read more https://t.co/wip7ggCPI0 #EconomicBulletin

A successful medical response in early 2021 is predicted to have a strong positive effect on economic activity but only a limited one on inflation. The new ECB-BASIR model seeks to better examine these effects of the pandemic. Read more https://t.co/AUymY2Ygy0 #EconomicBulletin

Weak demand is the main reason for low inflation in advanced economies during the pandemic. Supply constraints have had only a limited impact. Read more https://t.co/UdLv5soCDY #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/lGdMBqI8lQ
Euro area bank interest rate statistics (Dec 2020) https://t.co/LNCCjw8zc3

The latest Economic Bulletin is out! The Bulletin presents the economic and monetary information which forms the basis for our policy decisions. Read more https://t.co/fV809nM9qC https://t.co/GvxVSYRsqh

Leading companies tell us that business activity has been more resilient during the second wave of the pandemic than the first. The ECB is now starting to publish summaries of such dialogues with non-financial companies. Read more https://t.co/FQ0hgGu8PU #EconomicBulletin https://t.co/NQdmIY4SXT

Technological innovation brings benefits to banking customers, says Supervisory Board Member Pentti Hakkarainen. He explains how supervisors and regulators can best contribute to managing the process and emerging risks. Read the speech https://t.co/llh8Q5ht79 https://t.co/9BJEw2fXFy
